case_name: Kajori Lal Agarwal v. Union of India & Ors.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 666 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court by special leave from Calcutta High Court judgment dated July 6, 1959 in Civil Rule No. 3886 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 666 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order, dated July 6, 1959 of the Calcutta High Court in Civil Rule No. 388

facts.text: Appellant Kajori Lal Agarwal was owner-in-khas of 37.85 acres of land in Mouza Shibnath Das J.L. No. 110 and Mouza Kholai Singh J.L. No. 112 in Siliguri Town, Darjeeling district.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant Kajori Lal Agarwal was the owner-in-khas of 37.85 acres of land in Mouza Shibnath Das J. L. No. 110 and Mouza Kholai Singh J. L. No. 112 in Siliguri Town in the district

facts.text: Lands acquired by Union of India (respondent 1) and State of West Bengal (respondent 2) under West Bengal Land Requisition and Acquisition Act, 1948 (No. 2 of 1948) for Assam Rail Link Project.

anchor.surface_text: The said lands were acquired by the Union of India, and the State of West Bengal, respondents 1 2 respectively, under the relevant provisions of the West Bengal Land  Requisition and Acquis

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 is the Land Acquisition Officer, Darjeeling.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3 is the Land Acquisition Officer, Darjeeling.

facts.text: Appellant claimed compensation at Rs. 100 per cottah amounting to Rs. 2,27,100 plus Rs. 8,000 for severance and other grounds.

anchor.surface_text: In those proceedings, the appellant claimed companypensation at a flat rate of Rs. 100 per companytah amounting to Rs. 2,27,100. He also put in a claim for Rs. 8,000 on account of the severance and other grou

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 made award under s.7 of the Act on February 5, 1951 directing payment of Rs. 22,074 at Rs. 600 per acre.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3 made an award under s. 7 of the Act on the 5th February, 1951 directing the payment of Rs. 22,074 to the appellant in lieu of his lands at the rate of Rs. 600 per acre.

facts.text: Notice served on appellant under s.12(2) of Land Acquisition Act, 1894 after the award.

anchor.surface_text: After the award was pronounced, a numberice was served on the appellant under s. 12 2  of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894  No. 1 of 1894   hereinafter called the Central Act .

facts.text: Appellant accepted the compensation amount under protest on March 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On the 21st March, 1951, the appellant accepted the said amount as companypensation money under protest.

facts.text: Appellant filed application to respondent No. 3 on February 2, 1953 for reference to court under s.8 claiming award inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant filed an application before respondent No. 3 on the 2nd February, 1953 and claimed that a reference should be made by him to the Court for decision of his claim for a larg

facts.text: Respondent No. 3 rejected appellant's application for reference as barred by time.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 3 rejected the appellants application for reference on the ground that it was barred by time.

facts.text: Appellant challenged rejection by filing Civil Revision Case No. 676 of 1954 in Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant challenged the validity of this order by moving the Calcutta High Court in its revisional jurisdiction  Civil Revision Case No. 676 of 1954 .

facts.text: On June 16, 1955, Division Bench of Calcutta High Court allowed appellant's revision, remanded to respondent No. 3 to deal with application per law, observed no limitation but must be within reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th June, 1955, a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court allowed the appellants revisional application and sent the case to respondent No. 3 with a direction that the appellants applicatio

facts.text: Appellant filed affidavit on August 27, 1956 explaining delay in application for reference.

anchor.surface_text: After the appellants application was thus remanded to respondent No. 3, he filed an affidavit on the 27th August, 1956 and explained in detail the reasons for the delay made by him in filing his app

facts.text: On September 10, 1956, respondent No. 3 rejected appellant's application again for not moving within reasonable time.

anchor.surface_text: On the 10th September, 1956 respondent No. 3 rejected the appellants application on the ground that he had neglected to move for reference within a reasonable time.

facts.text: Appellant challenged order by filing Civil Rule No. 3886 of 1956 under Art. 227 Constitution and s.115 CPC in Calcutta High Court.

anchor.surface_text: This order was challenged by the appellant again by moving the Calcutta High Court under Art. 227 of the Constitution read with s. 115 of the Code of Civil Procedure  Civil Rule No. 3886 of 1956 .

facts.text: On July 6, 1959, Division Bench of Calcutta High Court dismissed appellant's application, finding no reason to interfere with respondent No. 3's order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 8 of the Act reads thus Reference to Court. 8.  1  The Collector shall in every case--  a  where any person aggrieved by an award made under sub-section  2  of section 7 makes an application requiring the matter to be referred to the Court or  b  where there is any disagreement with regard to the companypensation payable under sub- section  3  of section 7 between the Collector and the person to whom possession of any land is delivered under section 6 refer the matter to the decision of the Court. The provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894  No. 1 of 1894 , shall mutatis mutandis apply in respect of any reference made to the Court under sub-section  1 .

anchor.surface_text: After the award was pronounced, a numberice was served on the appellant under s. 12 2  of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894  No. 1 of 1894   hereinafter called the Central Act .

Section 18 of the Central Act reads thus 18.  1  Any person interested who has number accepted the award may, by written application to the Collector, require that the matter be referred by the Collector for the determination of the Court, whether his objection be to the measurement of the land, the amount of the companypensation, the persons to whom it is payable, or the apportionment of the companypensation among the persons interested The a application shall state the grounds on which objection to the award is taken  a  if the person making it was present or represented before the Collector at the time when he made his award, within six weeks from the date of the Collectors award  b  in other cases, within six weeks of the receipt of the numberice from the Collector under section 12, subsection  2 , or within six months from the date of the Collectors award, whichever period shall first expire.

arguments.claim: No prescribed period of limitation for application under s.8 per Birendra Nath Ray Sarkar v. Union of India

anchor.surface_text: the Calcutta High Court had ruled in the case of Birendra Nath Ray Sarkar Another v. Union of India Another  2   Civil Rule No. 2940 of 1951  that there was no prescribed period of limitation for an application for reference under s. 8 of the Act

arguments.claim: Provisions of LA Act apply mutatis mutandis via s.8(2) WB Act from the stage of application for reference, including s.18(2) limitation

anchor.surface_text: Having regard to the scheme of s. 8, considered in the light of the other provisions of the Act, it seems to us clear that the object of the Legislature in making the relevant provisions of the Central Act applicable to references was to take in all the relevant provisions of the Central Act which had reference to the making of reference and naturally, these provisions would begin with s.18 of the Central Act

arguments.claim: Clause 'in respect of any reference made to the Court' in s.8(2) includes references intended, proposed or asked for, not just after made

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error in reading the clause in respect of any reference made to the Court in s. 8  2  of the Act as referring to cases where reference has already been made. In the context, what the clause means is that the provisions of the Central Act shall mutatis mutandis apply in respect. of any reference intended, proposed, or asked, to be made

arguments.claim: Mandatory language in s.8(1) WB Act ('shall refer') does not exclude application of limitation provisions

anchor.surface_text: It is true that S. 8 1  of the Act uses the mandatory words the Collector shall refer the matter to the decision of the Court but that does not mean that it necessarily excludes the application of the provision as to limitation. Section 18 1  of the Central Act, though somewhat differently worded, has in law the same effect.

arguments.claim: Legislature unlikely to intend no limitation, leaving applications to parties' sweet will; would lead to anomalies

anchor.surface_text: On principle, it seems extremely unlikely that the Act which deals with acquisition and requisition of properties, could have intended to leave it to the sweet-will of the parties to make an application for reference at any time they like. The High Court no doubt realised the anomalies which would result

arguments.claim: 1954 amendment to s.8(2) expressly including s.18(2) LA Act supports that original provision applied limitation to applications

anchor.surface_text: It appears that presumably as a result of the decision of the Calcutta High Court, s. 8  2  of the Act has been amended by Act VIII of 1954. ... Even so, the clause that these provisions will apply in respect of any reference made to the Court under sub-section  1  still occurs in the amended provision

arguments.claim: Appellant's application of 2 Feb 1953 barred by limitation under s.8(2) WB Act read with s.18(2) LA Act

anchor.surface_text: Since we hold that the application originally made by the appellant to respondent No. 3 under s. 8 1  of the Act on the 2nd February, 1953 for reference, was barred by time

arguments.claim: No need to consider reasonable time as statutory limitation applies

anchor.surface_text: it is not necessary to consider the appellants plea whether it was made within a reasonable time. Section 8 2  of the Act read with S. 18 2  of the Central Act specifically prescribes limitation

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in holding that no period of limitation is prescribed by s. 8 of the West Bengal Land (Requisition and Acquisition) Act, 1948 for making an application for reference to court.

anchor.surface_text: Before we deal with this argument, however, it is necessary to consider the basic question as to whether the Calcutta High Court is right in holding that no period of limitation is prescribed by S. 8 of the Act for making an application for reference.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.8 requires provisions of Land Acquisition Act including s.18(2) limitation to apply from application stage via mutatis mutandis; textual reading of 'in respect of any reference made' includes proposed references; purposive to avoid unlimited time; supported by 1954 amendment.

holdings.text: The phrase 'in respect of any reference made to the Court under sub-section (1)' in s.8(2) means provisions of Land Acquisition Act apply mutatis mutandis to any reference intended, proposed or asked to be made.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court was in error in reading the clause in respect of any reference made to the Court in s. 8 2  of the Act as referring to cases where reference has already been made. In the context, what the clause means is that the provisions of the Central Act shall mutatis mutandis apply in respect. of any reference intended, proposed, or asked, to be made

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual and purposive interpretation; aligns with overall scheme beginning with s.18; unreasonable to apply only post-reference.

holdings.text: The mandatory language 'the Collector shall refer' in s.8(1) does not exclude application of limitation provisions from Land Acquisition Act s.18(2).

anchor.surface_text: It is true that S. 8 1  of the Act uses the mandatory words the Collector shall refer the matter to the decision of the Court but that does not mean that it necessarily excludes the application of the provision as to limitation. Section 18 1  of the Central Act, though somewhat differently worded, has in law the same effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to s.18(1) LA Act which is also mandatory but subject to limitation in s.18(2); rule application.

holdings.text: The appellant's application under s.8(1) dated 2nd February 1953 was barred by limitation under s.8(2) read with s.18(2) of Land Acquisition Act.

anchor.surface_text: Since we hold that the application originally made by the appellant to respondent No. 3 under s. 8 1  of the Act on the 2nd February, 1953 for reference, was barred by time, it is number necessary

holdings.reasoning_summary: Award on 5 Feb 1951; notice under s.12(2) served after; accepted under protest 21 Mar 1951; application exceeds 6 weeks/6 months periods.

holdings.text: Unnecessary to consider whether appellant's application was within reasonable time as statutory limitation applies.

anchor.surface_text: it is not necessary to consider the appellants plea whether it was made within a reasonable time. Section 8 2  of the Act read with S. 18 2  of the Central Act specifically prescribes limitation

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.8(2) and s.18(2) provide specific limitation periods supplanting reasonable time doctrine.

holdings.text: The appeal fails and the High Court order is confirmed though on different grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The result is, the appeal fails, and the order passed by the High Court is confirmed, though on different grounds.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application time-barred under correct interpretation of limitation provisions.

Section 18 1  of the Central Act, though somewhat differently worded, has in law the same effect.
The result is, the appeal fails, and the order passed by the High Court is companyfirmed, though on different grounds.

edges.explanation: Holding h4 applying limitation to bar the specific application addresses the core issue of limitation under s.8.
